entry.et: Middle English bryke, from Middle Dutch bricke

def.dt: :a handy-sized unit of building or paving material typically being rectangular and about 21/4 × 33/4 × 8 inches (57 × 95 × 203 millimeters) and of moist clay hardened by heat
:a rectangular compressed mass (as of ice cream)
:a semisoft cheese with numerous small holes, smooth texture, and often mild flavor
:gaffe blunder used especially in the phrase drop a brick
:a badly missed shot in basketball he threw up a brick
:to close, face, or pave with bricks usually used with up, in, or over
:relating to or being a traditional business serving customers in a building as contrasted to an online business a brick–and–mortar store
:an immovable block or obstruction the plan ran into a brick wall
